ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: ABSOLUTELY NOTHING. THIS COURSE IS REALLY POORLY TAUGHT.
basic probability, max likelihood estimation, calculating confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, understanding the difference between parameters and statistics, expectation
It was a pretty comprehensive introduction to statistics and inference. Much of the material we learned was not at all what I expected, but in a good way. I feel like I learned a lot!
Learned more about statistics
Fundamental concepts and theories in probability and statistics.
I learned the core skills of statistics and probability and interesting applications in Economics. I was also able to do some coding to facilitate understanding of the course content.
Basic probability and confidence intervals

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There is no positive. Slides were terrible, teaching was terrible, TF was terrible, Homeworks were WAY WAY TOO LONG and repetitive. Exams were very poorly written, and hardly related to anything in the psets. Moment functions constituted a large part of the final, and was extremely poorly taught..

Reading off the slides was not a very engaging format of lecturing. I wouldve preferred something closer to a math class, where key concepts are derived on the board. I learned most of the concepts through the textbook
I think an increased amount of practice questions with each lecture could be helpful, sometimes I find its hard to know where our gaps in understanding lie.
the lectures could have been more engaging
Very well-organized with clear lectures and helpful homework. The exams were a lot harder compared to the homework and were graded very strictly, but the final curve is quite generous.
The course notes were really clear and very helpful for the exams. There was also a component of computer programming, which I found to be very helpful.

Very low workload. Not very intrinsically interesting content, but that's just par for the course. Exams were fine--I would suggest getting quick at using control-F on the textbook pdf. The course didn't really hold me accountable for internalizing any of the material since the textbook problems (assigned once every two weeks) were kind of plug-and-chug, and the content itself just isn't that conceptually demanding. Prof. Narita was chill and knowledgeable.
Lectures unclear, had to learn everything nyself, no feedback from TAs on the midterm

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Never in a million years. Take anything else but this. You don't need it. If you need it for your major, you picked a dumb major.

This class teaches statistics at the appropriate mathematical level you need to actually grasp whats going on. I took the GLBL 121/122 sequence and that class left out lots of important concepts that you actually need to know in order to have a good grasp of statistics. I would recommend this class over that, but maybe not over S&DS 241/242. Lectures werent very useful and you learn most of the content on your own from the textbook.
I would, but a student should try to make use of the resources that are available. For example office hours and attending TA sessions is a must.
No, this was an extremely difficult course and there was minimal effort to ensure that we understood the material. I should've self-studied all of this.
Sure
I would recommend if you are interested in gaining a solid foundation in stats with econ applications.
I would recommend this course to any students who want to get a solid foundation of the core concepts in probability and statistics in one course.
Not really unless it's required. 241 and 238 are both probably better. Not anyone's fault, but the syllabus / content just doesn't give you much to sink your teeth into.
Only if you have to take it, and even then I would consider the 241-242 combination.
